questions.text: Strongest attachment of retina to vitreous is at
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The strongest attachment of the vitreous to the retina is at the vitreous base, which is located near the ora serrata. The vitreous base represents a broad, firm adhesion of the vitreous to the peripheral retina and pars plana.
  • Vitreous Attachments:
    • The vitreous is attached to several structures within the eye:
      • Peripheral retina and pars plana: This region, known as the vitreous base (I in the image), represents the strongest attachment.
      • Macula (III in the image): There is an attachment to the macula.(Option D ruled out)
      • Optic nerve (IV in the image): An attachment exists near the optic nerve.(Option B ruled out)
      • Retinal vessels (V in the image): The vitreous is also attached along the retinal vessels.
      • Posterior lens capsule (II in the image): There is also an attachment to the posterior lens capsule. (Option A ruled out)
    • The weakest attachment of the vitreous is along the retinal vessels.

Explanation of Other Options:

Lens (Option A): While the vitreous is attached to the posterior lens capsule (labeled II in the image), this is not described as the strongest attachment point.

Near Optic nerve (Option B): The vitreous is attached near the optic nerve (labeled IV in the image), but this attachment is not the strongest. Strong traction here can lead to optic disc avulsion or macular holes.

At macula (Option D): The vitreous has an attachment at the macula (labeled III in the image), but this is not the strongest attachment. Traction here can lead to vitreomacular traction syndrome or macular holes.

Key Takeaways:

  • The vitreous base, located near the ora serrata, represents the strongest anatomical attachment of the vitreous to the retina and pars plana.
  • The vitreous also has attachments to the macula, optic nerve, and retinal vessels, with the attachment along the retinal vessels being the weakest.

questions.text: Asteroid hyalosis contains
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Asteroid hyalosis is a degenerative condition of the vitreous humor characterized by the presence of small, glistening, yellowish-white particles. These particles are primarily composed of calcium

Explanation of Other Options:

Cholesterol (option B): Cholesterol deposits are characteristic of synchysis scintillans, a different vitreous condition, not asteroid hyalosis.

Lipids (option C): The primary and most specific component of asteroid hyalosis is calcium, even though the deposits are calcium-lipid complexes. Lipids alone are not the defining characteristic.

Copper (option D): Copper deposits are associated with different ocular conditions, such as Kayser-Fleischer rings in the cornea in Wilson's disease, or chalcosis (from intraocular copper foreign bodies). They are not a component of asteroid hyalosis.

questions.text: Collagen type most commonly seen in vitreous is
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The vitreous humor contains collagen fibrils that are heterotypic (mixed) in their composition. Among the various collagen types present, Type II collagen is the most common and predominates in the vitreous.
  • Composition of Vitreous Collagen Fibrils:
    • Vitreous collagen fibrils are composed of a mixture of collagen types, including Type II, Type V/XI, and Type IX.
    • Type II collagen is the most abundant type.
    • These collagen molecules are cross-linked, which provides mechanical stability to the fibrils within the vitreous.

Explanation of Other Options:

Type I (option A): Type I collagen is the most abundant collagen in the human body, found in connective tissues such as skin, bone, tendons, and ligaments. It is not the predominant type in the vitreous.

Type III (option C): Type III collagen is found in extensible connective tissues like skin, blood vessels, and internal organs, often alongside Type I collagen. It is not the predominant type in the vitreous.

Type IV (option D): Type IV collagen is a major component of basement membranes, providing structural support to epithelial and endothelial cells. It is not found in the vitreous fibrils.

Key Takeaways:

  • The vitreous humor's structural integrity is primarily attributed to collagen fibrils, with Type II collagen being the most predominant type.
  • Other collagen types, such as V/XI and IX, also contribute to the vitreous's complex structure.

questions.text: Maximum cones are present at
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The foveola is the region where cones are found in their maximum number and are most densely packed. It is the most specialized part of the macula for high-acuity vision.
  • Retinal Anatomy and Photoreceptor Distribution:
    • Foveola: This is the central 0.35 mm diameter area of the macula. It is the second thinnest region of the retina. Critically, the foveola contains the maximum number of cones and is entirely devoid of rods and ganglion cell layers.
    • Fovea: This is a larger area, about 1.85 mm in diameter, which includes the foveola. While cones are tightly packed here, the absolute maximum density is within the foveola. It corresponds to about 5 degrees of the visual field.
    • Foveal Avascular Zone (FAZ): This region lies outside the foveola but within the fovea. It is characterized by the absence of capillaries.
    • Perifoveal region: This area, approximately 1.5 mm around the fovea, is where the maximum number of rods are found.

Explanation of Other Options:

Fovea (option A): The fovea contains tightly packed cones and is the area of sharpest vision. However, the highest density and maximum number of cones are specifically within its central part, the foveola.

Foveal vascular region (option C): This term is not standard anatomical terminology for a region of cone concentration. The foveal avascular zone (FAZ) within the fovea is specifically without capillaries, not a region known for maximal cone concentration.

Optic nerve (option D): The optic nerve head (optic disc) is the blind spot of the retina as it contains no photoreceptors (rods or cones). It is the exit point for retinal ganglion cell axons.

Key Takeaways:

  • The foveola is the site of the highest concentration of cones in the retina, essential for central and high-acuity vision.
  • The fovea is a broader region that includes the foveola, and while rich in cones, the foveola holds the peak density.
  • Rods are absent in the foveola but reach their maximum concentration in the perifoveal region.

questions.text: True about retinal anatomy is all except
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The statement "Outer four layers receive blood from retinal arteries" is incorrect. The outer layers of the retina receive their blood supply from the choroid, specifically the choriocapillaries, not the retinal artery. The retinal artery primarily supplies the inner layers of the retina.
  • Key Aspects of Retinal Anatomy and Physiology:
    • Retinal Blood Supply:
      • Inner retinal layers are supplied by branches of the central retinal artery (CRA).
      • Outer four layers (photoreceptor layer, outer nuclear layer, outer plexiform layer, and inner segments of photoreceptors) receive their blood supply from the choroidal circulation (choriocapillaries).
      • The macula receives blood supply from both branches of the CRA and choriocapillaries.
      • The fovea itself is avascular.
    • Retinal Pigment Epithelium (RPE):
      • The RPE contains Na+/K+ ATPase pumps and melanin pigment.
      • The tight junctions and gap junctions of the RPE form the outer Blood-Retinal Barrier (BRB).
      • Tall RPE cells are present at the fovea.
    • Retinal Transparency:
      • Retinal transparency is maintained by various factors, including the Na+/K+ ATPase pump activity, which actively keeps fluid out of the retina.
      • The RPE barrier, formed vitreous, and oncotic pressure also contribute to maintaining retinal transparency.
    • Interphotoreceptor Matrix (IPM):
      • Binds the neurosensory retina (NSR) and RPE.
      • Composed of glycosaminoglycans, hyaluronic acid, and matrix metalloproteinases (MMPs).
    • Cilioretinal artery:
      • A branch of the Posterior Ciliary Artery.
      • Present in about 15% of the population.
      • Supplies the macula in addition to the Central Retinal Artery (CRA).

Explanation of Other Options:

Fovea has tall RPE cells (Option B): This statement is true. The RPE cells at the fovea are indeed taller than in other retinal regions.

Outer BRB is from RPE (Option C): This statement is true. The tight junctions between the RPE cells form the outer blood-retinal barrier, controlling the passage of substances between the choroid and the outer retina.

Pump activity is important for retinal transparency (Option D): This statement is true. The Na+/K+ ATPase pump activity, particularly in the RPE, is crucial for regulating fluid balance and maintaining the retina's deturgescence and transparency.

Key Takeaways:

  • The retina has a dual blood supply: inner layers from the retinal artery and outer layers from the choroid.
  • The RPE is critical for retinal function, forming the outer BRB and playing a key role in fluid transport and maintaining transparency.
  • The fovea's specialized anatomy includes tall RPE cells and an avascular zone.

questions.text: Most radio resistant layer of retina is
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • In the context of the retina, the Ganglion Cell Layer is identified as the most radioresistant This means it is the least susceptible to damage from radiation compared to other retinal layers.
  • Radiosensitivity of Ocular Structures:
    • Retina:
      • Most Radiosensitive: Photoreceptors (rods and cones).
      • Most Radioresistant: Ganglion cell layer.
    • Overall Eye:
      • Most Radiosensitive:
      • Most Radioresistant:

Explanation of Other Options:

Nerve fibre layer (Option A): While adjacent to the ganglion cell layer, the nerve fiber layer is not identified as the most radioresistant layer of the retina.

RPE (Option C): The Retinal Pigment Epithelium (RPE) plays a crucial role in maintaining photoreceptor health, but it is not the most radioresistant layer.

ONL (Option D): The Outer Nuclear Layer (ONL) contains the nuclei of the photoreceptors. Since photoreceptors are the most radiosensitive cells, their nuclear layer would not be the most radioresistant.

Key Takeaways:

  • Understanding the radiosensitivity of different ocular structures is important, especially in contexts involving radiation exposure.
  • For the retina, photoreceptors are highly sensitive to radiation, while the ganglion cell layer shows the greatest resistance.
  • Overall, the lens is the most radiosensitive part of the eye, and the sclera is the most radioresistant.

questions.text: Normal ratio of artery: vein in retina is
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The normal artery-to-venous caliber ratio (AV ratio) in the retina is 2:3. This ratio refers to the typical relative diameter of a retinal artery compared to its accompanying vein.
  • Characteristics of Retinal Vessels:
    • Retinal arteries are end arteries, meaning they do not form anastomoses with other arteries to supply the same area.
    • They typically branch dichotomously (divide into two branches).
    • Anastomoses (connections between blood vessels) in the retina primarily occur at the lamina cribrosa.

Key Takeaways:

  • The normal artery-to-venous caliber ratio (AV ratio) in the retina is 2:3. This is an important clinical indicator, as deviations can suggest underlying vascular pathology like hypertension or arterial sclerosis.

questions.text: CRAO can be seen In
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Central Retinal Artery Occlusion (CRAO) is a rare but severe manifestation of Rhino-Orbital-Cerebral Mucormycosis (ROCM), with an incidence ranging from 16% to 20%. In this context, CRAO is attributed to the direct infiltration of a central retinal artery by the angioinvasive fungal infection originating from the orbit.
  • Clinical Manifestations of Orbital Mucormycosis (relevant to CRAO):
    • As the fungal infection progresses, later symptoms may indicate invasion of orbital nerves and vessels. These can include:
      • Facial or periorbital swelling or numbness.
      • Blurred vision.
      • Chemosis (swelling of the conjunctiva).
      • Proptosis (forward displacement of the eyeball).
      • Diplopia (double vision).
      • Ophthalmoplegia (paralysis or weakness of eye muscles).
      • Corneal anesthesia.
      • Loss of vision, which can be due to CRAO.

Explanation of Other Options:

DM (Option A): While Diabetes Mellitus (DM) is a major risk factor for various retinal vascular diseases (like diabetic retinopathy and retinal vein occlusions), and can indirectly increase the risk of CRAO through systemic atherosclerosis, it is not a direct cause of CRAO in the same specific, invasive manner as mucormycosis of the orbit.

CMV retinitis (Option B): Cytomegalovirus (CMV) retinitis is an opportunistic infection primarily seen in immunocompromised individuals. It causes retinal necrosis and can lead to vascular occlusions (both arterial and venous), but it is not typically cited as a direct cause of CRAO via orbital invasion in the way mucormycosis is. Its occlusions are usually due to direct viral effects on retinal vessels.

Tuberculosis (Option D): Tuberculosis can affect the eye in various ways, including choroiditis, uveitis, and vasculitis. However, it is not commonly associated with direct orbital invasion leading to CRAO in the manner described for mucormycosis.

Key Takeaways:

  • CRAO can be a severe ocular complication of Rhino-Orbital-Cerebral Mucormycosis (ROCM).
  • The mechanism involves direct angioinvasive fungal infiltration of the central retinal artery from the orbit.
  • Other orbital signs of mucormycosis include swelling, proptosis, and ophthalmoplegia.

questions.text: A young diabetic of 38 years presents to your OPD with H/O transient blurred vision two episodes. Which test should be best to evaluate his symptoms
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • In a young individual, especially a diabetic, presenting with a history of transient blurred vision (which can be indicative of transient ischemic attacks like amaurosis fugax or a transient Central Retinal Artery Occlusion - CRAO), serum homocysteine levels should be checked. Elevated homocysteine is a risk factor for thrombotic events, including those affecting ocular circulation.
  • Clinical Relevance in Young Individuals:
    • Transient blurred vision or amaurosis fugax can be a symptom of a transient ischemic attack affecting the eye (e.g., transient CRAO).
    • While diabetes itself is a risk factor for vascular disease, in young individuals, less common causes of CRAO or other vascular events need to be explored.
    • Hyperhomocysteinemia is an independent risk factor for various vascular diseases and thrombophilia, making it crucial to evaluate in younger patients with unexplained vascular events, including those affecting the eye.
  • Causes of CRAO in Young Individuals:
    • Causes for CRAO in young individuals, including:
      • Hypercoagulable state
      • Hyperhomocysteinemia
      • Hyperlipidemia
      • Polycythemia
      • Thrombocytosis
      • Protein S Deficiency
      • Anti-cardiolipin Antibody
      • Anti-phospholipid Antibody
      • Oral Contraceptive Pills
      • Renal Disorder
      • Isolated Hypertension
      • Cardiac Abnormality (e.g., Rheumatic Heart Disease, Mitral Regurgitation, Aortic Regurgitation, Mitral Valve Prolapse)
      • Vasculitis (e.g., Systemic Lupus Erythematosus, Tuberculosis / Syphilis)

Explanation of Other Options:

Fasting BS levels (Option A): While the patient is diabetic, and blood sugar control is vital for overall diabetic management, transient blurred vision in a young diabetic, especially if suggesting an ischemic event, warrants investigation beyond just routine blood sugar levels to find the specific cause of the transient events.

MRI brain (Option B): An MRI brain is primarily used to evaluate neurological symptoms like stroke or brain lesions. While it might be considered if central neurological causes are suspected, it is not the best initial test specifically for transient blurred vision suggesting an ocular vascular event in this context, where systemic thrombotic risk factors are prioritized.

X ray cervical spine (Option D): An X-ray of the cervical spine would be indicated for neck pain, trauma, or suspected spinal pathologies. It has no direct relevance to evaluating transient blurred vision related to ocular vascular events.

Key Takeaways:

  • Transient blurred vision in a young diabetic should prompt a thorough investigation for underlying vascular risk factors beyond just diabetes management.
  • Serum homocysteine levels are an important test in young individuals to screen for hypercoagulable states that can lead to ocular ischemic events like CRAO or amaurosis fugax.

questions.text: Treatment for CRAO is
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The treatment for Central Retinal Artery Occlusion (CRAO) involves several acute interventions aimed at dislodging the embolus and restoring blood flow, especially within the critical window period. These interventions include ocular massage (like digital massage), lowering intraocular pressure (IOP), and paracentesis, making "All of above" the correct comprehensive answer.
  • Treatment Modalities for CRAO:
    • Window Period: Treatment is most effective within 90 minutes of onset.
    • Ocular Massage: Ocular massage, often performed with a three-mirror contact lens or digitally, involves applying pressure for 10 seconds to obtain retinal artery pulsation. The goal is to dislodge the embolus.
    • Lowering IOP: Reducing the intraocular pressure (IOP) is crucial to facilitate the dislodgement of the embolus. This can be achieved through:
      • Paracentesis: Anterior chamber paracentesis is a procedure to rapidly lower IOP.
      • IOP-lowering drops: Topical medications can also be used to keep IOP low.
    • Carbogen: A mixture of 95% oxygen and 5% carbon dioxide (Carbogen) can be used to increase retinal blood flow.
    • Thrombolysis: This involves using medications to dissolve blood clots and can be considered in specific cases.
    • Vasodilators: Medications that cause blood vessels to widen can also be used to improve blood flow.

Key Takeaways:

  • Acute management of CRAO involves a multi-pronged approach within a narrow 90-minute window period.
  • Key interventions include ocular massage, rapid lowering of IOP (via paracentesis or drops), and potentially carbogen, thrombolysis, or vasodilators.

questions.text: Laser photocoagulation is done first in which quadrant
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • When performing Pan Retinal Photocoagulation (PRP), the laser treatment is typically done in a specific sequence across the retina. The inferior retina is lasered first. This sequencing helps manage potential complications and patient comfort during the multi-sitting procedure.
  • Pan Retinal Photocoagulation (PRP) Procedure:
    • Laser Type: PRP is commonly performed using an Argon or df Nd:YAG laser.
    • Mechanism: The treatment involves coagulating retinal protein, which converts hypoxic areas to total anoxia, thereby decreasing oxygen demand. This diverts oxygen to the normal retina and stops the release of Vascular Endothelial Growth Factor (VEGF).
    • Sittings: The procedure is typically done in 3-4 sittings.
    • Quadrant Order: The inferior retina is the first quadrant to be lasered.
    • Burn Parameters: Approximately 1200-1600 burns are applied, each with a size of 500 microns, leaving a space of one laser mark between burns.
    • Areas Spared: The macula, fovea, major vessels, and optic disc are intentionally spared during the procedure.
  • Side Effects of PRP:
    • Visual Field defects.
    • Parapapillary Nerve Fibre Layer defects.
    • Inflammation and pain.
    • Choroidal detachment, especially if excessive laser is done in one sitting.

Explanation of Other Options:

Superior (Option B): The superior quadrant is not typically the first area to be lasered in PRP. The inferior retina is preferred for initial treatment.

Central (Option C): The central retina, including the macula and fovea, is deliberately spared during PRP to preserve central vision.

Temporal (Option D): The temporal quadrant is not usually the first area treated in PRP; the inferior quadrant is prioritized.

Key Takeaways:

  • Pan Retinal Photocoagulation (PRP) is a laser treatment to manage retinal conditions, primarily by reducing hypoxia and VEGF.
  • The standard practice for PRP involves treating the inferior retina first.

questions.text: Proliferation is characterized by
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Proliferation, particularly in the context of diabetic retinopathy (Proliferative Diabetic Retinopathy or PDR), is fundamentally characterized by neovascularization. This refers to the abnormal formation of new blood vessels.
  • Characteristics of Proliferative Diabetic Retinopathy (PDR):
    • PDR is defined by neovascularization arising from the optic disc and retina.
    • These newly formed vessels are fragile and prone to causing complications such as preretinal and vitreous hemorrhage.
    • Subsequent fibrosis of these new vessels can create tractional forces on the retina, potentially leading to retinal detachment.
    • Neovascularization itself is a natural process where new microvascular networks form in response to poor local perfusion or ischemia, acting as collateral circulation.

Explanation of Other Options:

Bleeding (Option A): While bleeding (hemorrhage) is a consequence or complication of the fragile new vessels in proliferation, it is not the defining characteristic of "proliferation" itself. Neovascularization is the underlying proliferative process.

Venous changes (Option B): Venous changes like venous beading or loops are seen in severe non-proliferative diabetic retinopathy (NPDR) and indicate increasing ischemia, but they are not the hallmark of "proliferation" which specifically refers to new vessel growth.

Soft exudates (Option C): Soft exudates, also known as cotton wool spots, are microinfarcts in the nerve fiber layer caused by ischemia. They are characteristic of non-proliferative diabetic retinopathy (NPDR) and are not a feature of "proliferation" itself, though both conditions can coexist in the same eye at different stages of the disease.

Key Takeaways:

  • Neovascularization is the defining feature of proliferation, especially in the context of proliferative diabetic retinopathy (PDR).
  • This new vessel formation occurs in response to retinal ischemia and can lead to severe complications like hemorrhage and retinal detachment.

questions.text: All can be the eye manifestations in DM except
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Subconjunctival haemorrhage is typically not a direct eye manifestation of Diabetes Mellitus (DM), but rather is more commonly seen in hypertensives or due to other causes. Therefore, it is the exception among the listed options.
  • Eye Manifestations in Diabetes Mellitus (DM):
    • Rubeosis iridis: This is Neovascularization of the iris (NVI), a serious ocular manifestation of advanced diabetic retinopathy (Proliferative Diabetic Retinopathy, PDR). It involves the growth of new, abnormal blood vessels on the iris surface.
    • Neovascular glaucoma: This is a severe complication that arises from rubeosis iridis, where the new vessels on the iris and in the angle obstruct the aqueous outflow pathway, leading to a significant increase in intraocular pressure (IOP). It is a direct and serious manifestation of DM.
    • Paralysis of 3rd, 4th, or 6th nerve: Diabetic neuropathy can affect the cranial nerves controlling eye movements, leading to isolated or multiple ocular motor nerve palsies (e.g., affecting the oculomotor (3rd), trochlear (4th), or abducens (6th) nerves), causing diplopia. This is a recognized neurological complication of DM.
  • Causes of Subconjunctival Hemorrhage:
    • Most commonly caused by hypertension.
    • Can also result from actions that briefly raise blood pressure in veins, such as coughing, sneezing, straining, or similar actions, which can cause capillaries to break.
    • Trauma to the eye is another common cause.

Explanation of Other Options:

Rubeosis iridis (Option B): This is a direct and significant ocular manifestation of advanced diabetic retinopathy (PDR), characterized by neovascularization of the iris.

Neovascular glaucoma (Option C): This is a severe complication directly linked to advanced diabetic retinopathy (via rubeosis iridis), leading to high intraocular pressure and vision loss.

Paralysis of 3/4/6th nerve (Option D): Diabetic neuropathy can cause palsies of these cranial nerves, leading to diplopia (double vision), and is a recognized neurological manifestation of diabetes affecting the eye.

Key Takeaways:

  • While diabetes can cause a wide range of ocular complications, subconjunctival hemorrhage is typically not a direct manifestation of DM, but rather is more associated with hypertension or physical strain.
  • Rubeosis iridis, neovascular glaucoma, and cranial nerve palsies are all well-established ocular manifestations or complications of Diabetes Mellitus.

questions.text: Screening in ROP is done when
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Screening for Retinopathy of Prematurity (ROP) is indicated for infants with a gestational age of 34 weeks or less. Among the given options, birth at 28 weeks falls within this criterion, making it an indication for screening.
  • Screening Criteria for ROP:
    • Infants with birth weights of ≤2 Kg.
    • Gestational age of 34 weeks or less.
    • Infants with birth weight between 1500 and 2000 g with an unstable clinical course.
    • Other factors: Oxygen exposure for > 30 days, presence of respiratory distress syndrome, sepsis, multiple blood transfusions, multiple births, prolonged ICU stay, excessive oxygen delivery, or neonatologist's demand for screening.
  • Time of Screening:
    • Ideally, babies should be screened at 31 weeks post-conceptional age (gestational age + postnatal age) or 4 weeks after birth, whichever is later.
  • Retinopathy of Prematurity (ROP) Overview:
    • Also known as Terry's Disease.
    • Risk Factors (Most Important): Prematurity, low birth weight, and high oxygen exposure in NICU.
    • Etiopathogenesis: In premature infants, the retina is not fully vascularized. Excessive oxygen exposure leads to cessation of normal vessel growth, followed by ischemia and upregulation of VEGF, causing new, abnormal vessel growth towards the vitreous.
  • ROP Stages and Classifications:
    • Plus Disease: Characterized by extreme vascular tortuosity at the posterior pole, vitreous haze, and iris vessel engorgement in at least two clock hours.
    • Threshold Disease (by CRYO-ROP): Defined as 5 contiguous or 8 non-contiguous clock hours of Stage 3 ROP in Zone 1 or 2 with plus disease.
    • Early Treatment ROP (ETROP) study: Proved that earlier treatment at the Pre-Threshold stage leads to better outcomes. The study divided pre-threshold ROP into high-risk (Type 1) and low-risk (Type 2).
      • High Risk Prethreshold or Type 1 ROP (Indication for Treatment):
        • Zone 1 any stage with plus disease.
        • Zone 1 stage 3 without plus disease.
        • Zone 2 stage 2 or 3 with plus disease.
      • Low Risk Prethreshold Disease or Type 2 ROP:
        • Zone 1 stage 1 or 2 without plus disease.
        • Zone 2 stage 3 without plus disease.
    • AP ROP (Aggressive Posterior ROP) aka Rush Disease: Plus disease at the posterior pole, which usually progresses to Stage 5 if untreated.
  • Treatment:
    • Cryotherapy is performed on the avascular retina.
    • Laser photocoagulation (by diode laser 810nm) is used, causing less inflammation and requiring only topical anesthesia.
    • Lens-sparing PPV (Pars Plana Vitrectomy) is done for Stage 4b and 5 ROP.

Explanation of Other Options:

Weight is < 2500 gm (Option A): While low birth weight is a risk factor, the specific cutoff for screening is ≤2 Kg (2000 gm), not 2500 gm.

Birth at 34 weeks (Option C): Birth at 34 weeks is a criterion for screening. However, the question asks "when," and "birth at 28 weeks" is also a valid and more severe criterion that necessitates screening. Both B and C are correct criteria. Given the options, 28 weeks represents an earlier and thus a more definite trigger for screening if the range is 34 weeks or less. Without further clarification on "best," 28 weeks is unequivocally within the screening gestational age.

Neonatal seizure (Option D): Neonatal seizure is a neurological symptom and not a direct criterion for ROP screening. While it might indicate other neonatal complications, it's not a primary factor in the ROP screening guidelines.

Key Takeaways:

  • ROP screening is crucial for premature infants.
  • Key screening criteria include a gestational age of 34 weeks or less or a birth weight of ≤2 Kg.
  • Screening ideally begins at 31 weeks post-conceptional age or 4 weeks after birth, whichever is later.

questions.text: All are considered emergencies in eye except
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • CRVO (Central Retinal Vein Occlusion) is the exception among the listed conditions, as it is generally not considered an emergency in ophthalmology in the same immediate, sight-threatening way as the other conditions. While serious, its management is typically not as time-critical as arterial occlusions or infections.
  • Common Ocular Emergencies:
    • Ischemic optic neuropathy: Requires immediate evaluation to rule out giant-cell arteritis (GCA).
    • Central retinal artery occlusion (CRAO): A true emergency requiring urgent intervention within a narrow window period to rule out GCA and causes of emboli/thrombus.(Option D ruled out)
    • Mac-on rhegmatogenous retinal detachment: Requires urgent surgical intervention to prevent vision loss.
    • Acute third nerve palsy: Needs urgent investigation to rule out intracranial aneurysm.
    • Open globe: Requires urgent surgical repair to prevent severe vision loss and infection; rule out intraocular foreign body.
    • Acute angle closure glaucoma: A painful condition causing rapid vision loss due to high intraocular pressure, requiring immediate treatment.(Option C ruled out)
    • Endophthalmitis: A severe intraocular infection requiring urgent treatment to save the eye.
    • Alkali injury: Chemical injuries, especially alkali burns, require urgent and copious irrigation.
    • Orbital cellulitis: A severe infection of the tissues surrounding the eye, which can lead to vision loss or intracranial spread, necessitating urgent management. (Option B ruled out)

Key Takeaways:

  • While all serious, Central Retinal Vein Occlusion (CRVO) is typically not classified as an acute ocular emergency compared to conditions like CRAO, acute angle-closure glaucoma, or orbital cellulitis.
  • Ocular emergencies are conditions that require immediate medical attention to prevent permanent vision loss or severe systemic complications.

questions.text: Least prescribed drug for glaucoma in a diabetic patient with decrease in vision. When his OCT was done this OCT picture was seen
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • A diabetic patient with decreased vision and an associated OCT picture showing Cystoid Macular Edema. PG analogues (prostaglandin analogues) are a known cause of Cystoid Macular Edema (CME). Therefore, PG analogues would be the least prescribed drug for glaucoma in such a patient if CME is present or a concern, due to their potential to exacerbate or induce CME.
  • Cystoid Macular Edema (CME):
    • Mechanism: CME results from a generalized breakdown of the inner Blood-Retinal Barrier (BRB), with fluid accumulation primarily in the outer plexiform layer and inner nuclear layer of the retina.
    • Henle's Layer: At the fovea, this layer is known as Henle's layer, characterized by an oblique arrangement of cells.
    • Symptoms: Patients may experience central decrease in vision, a central scotoma, metamorphopsia (distortion of images), and micropsia (images appearing smaller because of separation of cone as fluid accumulates).
    • Signs: Ophthalmoscopy may reveal a "honeycomb" appearance, while fluorescein angiography shows a "flower petal" appearance.
    • Optical Coherence Tomography (OCT): A cystoid pattern appears on OCT, making it important for quantification and follow-up.
  • Causes of CME (DRIP Ur NOSE mnemonic):
    • D - Diabetic Retinopathy (DR)
    • R - Retinitis Pigmentosa
    • I - Irvine-Gass Syndrome
    • P - PG analogues, Pilocarpine
    • Ur - Uveitis
    • N - Niacin
    • O - Occlusion
    • S - Surgery
    • E - Epinephrine
  • Treatment Considerations for Diabetic Macular Edema (DME):
    • Corticosteroids: These agents possess anti-inflammatory, antiangiogenic, and antipermeability properties. They work by inhibiting macrophages that release angiogenic growth factors, down-regulating Intercellular Adhesion Molecule 1 (ICAM-1) (which mediates leukocyte adhesion), and altering the composition of the endothelial basal membrane.
    • Anti-VEGF: Anti-Vascular Endothelial Growth Factor (Anti-VEGF) agents can be administered.
    • Subthreshold laser: This type of laser photocoagulation can also be performed.

Explanation of Other Options:

Alpha agonist (Option A): Alpha agonists (e.g., Brimonidine) are used in glaucoma management and are generally considered safer regarding macular edema compared to PG analogues.

Beta blockers (Option C): Beta blockers (e.g., Timolol) are common first-line treatments for glaucoma that reduce aqueous humor production. They are generally not associated with causing or exacerbating CME.

Acetazolamide (Option D): Acetazolamide is a carbonic anhydrase inhibitor used in glaucoma to reduce aqueous humor production. It is also sometimes used systemically to treat CME, as it helps to pump fluid out of the retina. Therefore, it would not be the "least prescribed" drug if CME is present.

Key Takeaways:

  • PG analogues are a known cause of Cystoid Macular Edema (CME).
  • In a diabetic patient with CME or a high risk for it, PG analogues would be the least preferred glaucoma medication due to their potential to induce or worsen macular edema.
  • CME is a condition involving fluid accumulation in the macula, leading to visual symptoms and a characteristic appearance on imaging.

questions.text: Cherry red spot with hollenhorst plaque is seen in
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The presence of a cherry-red spot in the macula along with a Hollenhorst plaque is a classic combination seen in Central Retinal Artery Occlusion (CRAO), which can be caused by a thrombosis. The cherry-red spot results from retinal ischemia and edema, while the Hollenhorst plaque indicates an embolic source.
  • Key Clinical Signs and Emboli Types in CRAO:
    • Cherry-red spot: This appearance occurs due to acute ischemia of the inner retina. The macula, particularly the foveola, is thinner and lacks ganglion cells, allowing the underlying choroidal blood supply to show through, creating the red spot amidst the pale, edematous surrounding retina.
    • Hollenhorst plaque (Cholesterol emboli): These are yellow, refractile emboli typically located at the carotid artery bifurcation. They often originate from atherosclerotic lesions in the carotid arteries or the aorta.
    • Fibrinoplatelet emboli: These are dull grey, elongated, and usually multiple particles that may occasionally fill the entire lumen of an arteriole.
    • Calcific emboli: These originate from cardiac valve disease. They appear white, are usually solitary, and are commonly located on the optic disc. They can lead to major arterial occlusion.

Explanation of Other Options:

Eale's disease (Option A): Eale's disease is characterized by periphlebitis (inflammation of retinal veins) leading to recurrent vitreous hemorrhages and neovascularization, primarily affecting young males. It is not typically associated with a cherry-red spot or Hollenhorst plaques.

Retinitis pigmentosa (Option B): Retinitis pigmentosa is a group of inherited retinal dystrophies characterized by progressive photoreceptor degeneration, leading to night blindness and peripheral vision loss. It does not present a cherry-red spot or Hollenhorst plaques.

Central retinal vein occlusion (Option D): Central Retinal Vein Occlusion (CRVO) typically presents with diffuse retinal hemorrhages (blood and thunder appearance), dilated tortuous veins, and macular edema. A cherry-red spot is not a feature of CRVO, and while emboli can occur, Hollenhorst plaques are characteristic of arterial occlusion.

Key Takeaways:

  • The combination of a cherry-red spot and a Hollenhorst plaque is highly indicative of Central Retinal Artery Occlusion (CRAO).
  • Hollenhorst plaques are cholesterol emboli, commonly originating from carotid artery disease.

questions.text: A young adult male presented with sudden painless loss of vision. He recovered spontaneously within 3 months. His OCT picture is given here. Most likely cause of his blindness is
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The patient's presentation of sudden painless vision loss with spontaneous recovery within 3 months, coupled with an OCT showing neurosensory detachment, is highly characteristic of Central Serous Retinopathy (CSR). CSR is known for its spontaneous resolution in many cases.
  • Central Serous Retinopathy (CSR) Characteristics:
    • Pathophysiology: CSR involves hyper-permeable choroidal capillaries and retinal pigment epithelium (RPE) dysfunction, which together cause a serous detachment of the neurosensory retina at the macula.
    • Etiology/Risk Factors: Commonly seen in young males, particularly those with a stressful lifestyle, Type A personality, or a history of smoking, steroid use, OCP (oral contraceptive pill) usage, or pregnancy.
    • Symptoms: Patients typically present with a central scotoma or decreased central vision, often experiencing a hypermetropic shift (farsightedness).
    • Diagnosis (FFA): Fluorescein angiography (FFA) is performed to confirm the diagnosis.
      • Ink blot pattern: This is the most commonly seen pattern, where the leak increases and enlarges (enlarging dot sign).
      • Smoke stack pattern (aka mushroom or umbrella configuration): This pattern is more specific, showing hyperfluorescence rising vertically and then spreading laterally.
    • Prognosis & Treatment Indications:
      • Spontaneous resolution of fluid is common, especially if causative factors are removed.
      • Indications for treatment include: bilateral CSR, recurrent CSR, or in functionally monocular patients.
    • Modalities of Treatment:
      • Anti-VEGF: Can be given as VEGF levels may be elevated.
      • Argon laser subthreshold photocoagulation: This is used only in cases where the leak is well-defined and not subfoveal (i.e., not directly under the fovea).
      • Photodynamic Therapy (PDT): Involves using verteporfin as a photosensitizer agent, which accumulates in target regions and decreases choroidal hyperpermeability. A common protocol is a half-dose (3 mg/m$^2$) of verteporfin infused over 8 minutes, followed by a low-power laser applied for 83 seconds (690 nm). PDT is particularly useful for subfoveal CSR where laser photocoagulation cannot be done.

Explanation of Other Options:

Macular hole (Option B): A macular hole is a full-thickness defect in the fovea. While it causes central vision loss, spontaneous recovery is rare, and it typically does not involve neurosensory detachment in the way CSR does. The OCT would show a distinct foveal defect.

Myopic crescent (Option C): A myopic crescent is a benign finding in highly myopic eyes, representing an atrophy of the choroid and RPE adjacent to the optic disc. It causes a stable visual field defect, not sudden, transient vision loss, and is not associated with neurosensory detachment.

Vitreous hemorrhage (Option D): Vitreous hemorrhage can cause sudden painless vision loss due to blood obscuring the visual axis. While it can resolve spontaneously, the OCT would show blood in the vitreous cavity, not a neurosensory detachment of the macula, which is characteristic of CSR.

Key Takeaways:

  • Central Serous Retinopathy (CSR) is a common cause of sudden painless vision loss in young to middle-aged males, often linked to stress and steroid use.
  • Its hallmark is neurosensory detachment at the macula on OCT, and it frequently resolves spontaneously.
  • FFA helps identify the characteristic "ink blot" or "smoke stack" leakage patterns.

questions.text: A 50 year old diabetic came for a routine check up. She had diabetes and hypertension for 5 years. Her retina had some findings as in the picture. Not true about this patient
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The provided scenario describes a patient with findings consistent with Non-Proliferative Diabetic Retinopathy (NPDR), specifically moderate to severe NPDR, where Pan Retinal Photocoagulation (PRP) is generally not indicated. Therefore, the statement "PRP should be done" is not true about this patient. PRP is primarily reserved for Proliferative Diabetic Retinopathy (PDR) or severe non-proliferative stages.
  • Management of NPDR (Moderate-Severe):
    • PRP Indication: PRP is not indicated for NPDR. It is typically reserved for PDR or high-risk pre-threshold ROP (as previously discussed), where neovascularization is present.
    • Macular Edema: Macular edema appears to be absent in the provided picture, indicating no immediate need for macular-specific treatment.
    • Systemic Control: Strict diabetic and hypertensive control is crucial for preventing progression of diabetic retinopathy.(Option B ruled out)
    • Follow-up: Frequent follow-ups are essential for monitoring the disease progression. (Option A ruled out)
  • Retinal Examination Techniques:
    • Preventing blindness from retinopathy relies on early detection through fundus examination.
    • The fundus can be examined by ophthalmoscopy, or by slit lamp biomicroscopy using either a contact lens or a 78D lens. A 90D lens is also commonly used.(Option D ruled out)
    • Retinal photography, using conventional film or a digital camera, can also be employed.

Key Takeaways:

  • For Non-Proliferative Diabetic Retinopathy (NPDR), the primary management focuses on strict systemic control (diabetes and hypertension) and regular follow-up.
  • Pan Retinal Photocoagulation (PRP) is not indicated for NPDR unless it progresses to PDR or high-risk pre-threshold disease.
  • Slit lamp biomicroscopy with high-power lenses is standard for retinal examination, including assessing macular edema.

questions.text: Which of the following doesn't require treatment
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Among the given options, Severe non-proliferative diabetic retinopathy (NPDR) typically does not require immediate active treatment like laser or injections, unless it progresses to proliferative diabetic retinopathy (PDR) or develops clinically significant macular edema (CSME). While it requires close monitoring and strict systemic control, it's generally not an indication for direct ocular intervention in the same way as the other options.
  • Indications for Treatment in Diabetic Retinopathy (DR):
    • Proliferative Diabetic Retinopathy (PDR): This stage always requires active treatment, typically Pan Retinal Photocoagulation (PRP) or anti-VEGF injections, due to the presence of fragile new blood vessels.
    • Clinically Significant Macular Edema (CSME) or Diabetic Macular Edema (DME): This requires focal/grid laser, anti-VEGF injections, or steroids to reduce fluid and preserve central vision. (Option B ruled out)
    • Vitreous Hemorrhage (VH) with PDR: Vitreous hemorrhage often results from bleeding from fragile new vessels in PDR and typically warrants intervention, which could be laser, anti-VEGF, or vitrectomy depending on severity and chronicity.(Option A ruled out)
    • Tractional Retinal Detachment (TRD) involving the macula: This is a surgical emergency that requires vitrectomy to reattach the retina and prevent irreversible vision loss. (Option C ruled out)

Key Takeaways:

  • The primary indications for direct ocular treatment in diabetic retinopathy are Proliferative Diabetic Retinopathy (PDR) and Clinically Significant Macular Edema (CSME).
  • While Severe Non-Proliferative Diabetic Retinopathy (NPDR) requires close monitoring and aggressive systemic control, it is generally managed conservatively until it progresses to PDR or develops CSME.

questions.text: A person is diagnosed to have diabetes on his 45th birthday. When will you recommend dilated fundus examination
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • For a person diagnosed with Type 2 Diabetes, a dilated fundus examination should be performed immediately or as early as possible after diagnosis. This is because Type 2 diabetes often goes undiagnosed for some time, and retinopathy may already be present at the time of diagnosis.
  • Diabetic Retinopathy (DR) Screening Guidelines:
    • Duration of Diabetes: This is a major risk factor and the main criterion used to decide when to begin DR screening.
    • Type 1 Diabetes: In Type 1 diabetes, screening should begin after 5 years of diagnosis. The prevalence of retinopathy increases with duration: approximately 25% after 5 years, almost 60% after 10 years, and 80% after 15 years.
    • Type 2 Diabetes: In Type 2 diabetes, screening should be done as early as possible after diagnosis. This is crucial because many individuals with Type 2 diabetes may have had the condition for several years before diagnosis, potentially already developing retinopathy.

Key Takeaways:

  • The timing of dilated fundus examination for diabetic retinopathy depends on the type of diabetes.
  • For Type 2 diabetes, screening should be done immediately upon diagnosis.
  • For Type 1 diabetes, screening typically begins 5 years after diagnosis.
  • Early detection of asymptomatic retinopathy is vital for preventing vision loss.

questions.text: Gunn sign is
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Gunn's sign is a specific ophthalmoscopic finding in hypertensive retinopathy and arteriosclerosis, characterized by the tapering of veins on either side of an arteriovenous crossing. This occurs due to compression of the venule by a thickened arteriole sharing a common adventitial sheath.
  • Retinal Changes in Hypertension and Arteriosclerosis:
    • Hypertensive Retinopathy (Keith-Wagner-Barker classification):
      • Group 1: Slight constriction of retinal arterioles.
      • Group 2: Group 1 + focal narrowing of retinal arterioles + AV nicking.
      • Group 3: Group 2 + flame-shaped hemorrhages + cotton-wool spots + hard exudates.
      • Group 4: Group 3 + optic disc swelling.
    • Hypertensive Retinopathy (Stages):
      • Stage 1: Diffuse arteriolar narrowing.
      • Stage 2: Stage 1 + focal arteriolar constriction.
      • Stage 3: Stage 2 + retinal hemorrhage.
      • Stage 4: Stage 3 + hard exudates + retinal edema + optic disc swelling.
    • Arteriosclerosis (Stages):
      • Stage 1: Broadening of arteriolar light reflex.
      • Stage 2: Stage 1 + AV crossing changes.
      • Stage 3: Copper wiring of arterioles.
      • Stage 4: Silver wiring of arterioles.
    • AV crossing changes: These occur when a thickened arteriole crosses over a venule and compresses it because the vessels share a common adventitious sheath.
  • Specific Arteriovenous Crossing Signs:
    • Gunn's sign: Characterized by tapering of veins on either side of the arteriovenous crossing.
    • Bonnet sign: Refers to the dilatation of the veins distal to the arteriovenous crossing.
    • Salus sign: Describes an S-shaped deflection of veins at the arteriovenous crossing.

Explanation of Other Options:

Silver wiring of arterioles (Option A): Silver wiring is a sign of advanced arteriosclerosis (Stage 4), indicating severe narrowing and thickening of the arteriolar wall, making it appear as a white or silver line. It is not Gunn's sign.

Deflection of veins at arteriovenous crossing (Option B): While deflection of veins occurs at arteriovenous crossings, an S-shaped deflection is specifically known as Salus sign, not Gunn's sign.

Copper wiring of arterioles (Option C): Copper wiring is a sign of arteriosclerosis (Stage 3), indicating a less severe degree of arteriolar wall thickening than silver wiring, where the light reflex has a coppery sheen. It is not Gunn's sign.

Key Takeaways:

  • Gunn's sign specifically describes the tapering of veins on either side of an arteriovenous crossing due to arterial compression.
  • Other related signs like Bonnet's sign (venous dilatation distal to crossing) and Salus's sign (S-shaped venous deflection) also indicate arteriovenous crossing changes associated with hypertensive retinopathy and arteriosclerosis.

questions.text: 4-2-1 rule is for which retinal pathology
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The "4-2-1 rule" is a specific clinical grading criterion used for Diabetic Retinopathy (DR), particularly to classify severe Non-Proliferative Diabetic Retinopathy (NPDR).
  • The "4-2-1 Rule" for Severe NPDR:
    • A retina has severe NPDR if any of the following are met:
      • Hemorrhages or microaneurysms, or both, appear in all four retinal quadrants (the "4" in 4-2-1 rule).
      • Venous beading appears in two or more retinal quadrants (the "2" in 4-2-1 rule).
      • Prominent Intraretinal Microvascular Abnormalities (IRMAs) are present in at least one retinal quadrant (the "1" in 4-2-1 rule).

Explanation of Other Options:

Hypertensive retinopathy (Option B): Hypertensive retinopathy is classified using systems like the Keith-Wagner-Barker classification or stages based on arteriolar narrowing, hemorrhages, cotton-wool spots, and optic disc swelling, but not the "4-2-1 rule".

Retinal detachment (Option C): Retinal detachment is classified by its etiology (rhegmatogenous, tractional, exudative) and extent, and its diagnosis involves identifying a separation of the neurosensory retina from the RPE. The "4-2-1 rule" is not applicable to retinal detachment.

Trachoma (Option D): Trachoma is a chronic eye infection caused by Chlamydia trachomatis that affects the conjunctiva and cornea, leading to scarring and blindness. It is not a retinal pathology, and the "4-2-1 rule" is unrelated to its classification.

Key Takeaways:

  • The "4-2-1 rule" is a specific criterion for grading the severity of Non-Proliferative Diabetic Retinopathy (NPDR).
  • It helps identify eyes at high risk of progressing to Proliferative Diabetic Retinopathy (PDR)

questions.text: A 65 year old female came with progressive visual loss in her one eye since a few months on examination this picture was found. what is the not the causative risk factor for this
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • A patient with progressive visual loss and image showing macular hole, among the options, history of smoking is not a directly recognized causative risk factor for the development of a macular hole. While smoking is a risk factor for various other ocular conditions (like Age-related Macular Degeneration), it is not typically associated with macular hole formation.
  • Macular Hole Overview:
    • Definition: A macular hole is a full-thickness defect of the foveal retina, extending from the internal limiting membrane (ILM) to the outer segment of the photoreceptor layer.
    • Etiopathogenesis: The most common cause is tangential vitreoretinal traction.
    • Idiopathic: Over 90% of macular holes are idiopathic (of unknown cause).
    • Recognized Risk Factors:
      • Age: Increasing age is a significant risk factor.
      • Female gender.
      • Myopia.
      • Trauma: Ocular trauma can lead to macular holes.
      • Ocular inflammation.
      • Lasers in eye: Previous laser treatment in the eye can be a risk factor.
  • Stages of Macular Hole:
    • Stage 1: Foveal cyst / yellow dot.
    • Stage 2: Full thickness break < 400 microns, with or without a pseudo-operculum.
    • Stage 3: Full thickness break > 400 microns, with incomplete Posterior Vitreous Detachment (PVD).
    • Stage 4: Full thickness hole with complete PVD.
  • Treatment for Macular Hole:
    • The primary treatment is Pars Plana Vitrectomy (PPV) with ILM peeling (Internal Limiting Membrane peeling), often utilizing an inverted flap technique, followed by C3F8 gas injection for hole closure.

Explanation of Other Options:

Increasing age (Option A): Increasing age is the most common and significant risk factor for the development of idiopathic macular holes. This statement is a true causative risk factor.

Trauma (Option B): Ocular trauma is a recognized cause of macular holes, leading to traumatic macular holes. This statement is a true causative risk factor.

h/o lasers in eye (Option C): A history of previous laser treatment in the eye can sometimes induce or contribute to the formation of a macular hole. This statement is a true causative risk factor.

Key Takeaways:

  • A macular hole is a full-thickness defect in the fovea, primarily caused by vitreoretinal traction.
  • Common risk factors include increasing age, female gender, myopia, trauma, and ocular inflammation, and previous laser treatment.

questions.text: A young IT professional complaining of metamorphopsia since a month ago came to your OPD. After the clinical work up you decided to go for an OCT. What is the likely correct statements about this patient
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The patient's presentation of metamorphopsia (distortion of images) and the image showing neurosensory detachment in a young IT professional strongly suggest Central Serous Retinopathy (CSR). A significant risk factor for CSR, especially in young males (implied by "IT professional"), is stress, including stress at the workplace. Therefore, ruling out stress as a causative factor is a likely correct statement.
  • Central Serous Retinopathy (CSR) Characteristics:
    • OCT Findings: The provided image shows a neurosensory detachment, which is characteristic of CSR.
    • Etiology: Risk factors include young males, a stressful lifestyle, Type A personality, smoking, steroid use, OCP usage, and pregnancy. Stress is an important risk factor for CSR.
    • Symptoms: Common symptoms include central scotoma or decreased central vision (often with a hypermetropic error) and metamorphopsia (distortion of images).
    • Fluorescein Angiography (FFA) Findings: FFA is done to confirm the diagnosis and typically shows specific leakage patterns:
      • Ink blot pattern: This is the most commonly seen pattern, where the leak increases and enlarges (enlarging dot sign).
      • Smoke stack pattern (aka mushroom or umbrella configuration): This pattern is more specific, showing hyperfluorescence rising vertically and then spreading laterally.

Explanation of Other Options:

He must be a myopic (Option B): While myopia can be a risk factor for some retinal conditions, CSR is more often associated with hypermetropic error, and there is no strict requirement for the patient to be myopic.

FFA shows new vessels leak (Option C): FFA in CSR shows leakage from the choroid into the subretinal space, but it's typically a serous leak, not a "new vessels leak" in the sense of neovascularization as seen in conditions like PDR or AMD.

Petalloid appearance can be seen on FFA (Option D): A "flower petal" or "petalloid" appearance on FFA is characteristic of Cystoid Macular Edema (CME), not typically CSR. While CME can be a complication of various conditions, it's not the primary FFA pattern for CSR.

Key Takeaways:

  • Metamorphopsia in a young adult, along with OCT findings of neurosensory detachment, strongly points to Central Serous Retinopathy (CSR).
  • Stress (including work-related stress) is a significant predisposing factor for CSR.
  • FFA in CSR is characterized by ink blot or smoke stack leakage patterns, not necessarily new vessel leaks or a petalloid appearance.
